title: 109_s2302
content: The Act titled "Federal Emergency Management Improvement Act of 2006" establishes the Federal Emergency Management Agency and its Director and Deputy Director. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is established as an independent establishment in the executive branch. The Director of the agency is appointed by the President with Senate approval and must have significant experience in emergency preparedness. The Deputy Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, appointed by the President with Senate approval, must have significant experience in emergency preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation for natural disasters and national cataclysmic events. The Deputy Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is added as an executive schedule position under Section 5313 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 102. FUNCTIONS. The Federal Emergency Management Agency's functions include carrying out the Stafford Act, reducing risks from hazards through mitigation, planning for emergencies, and responding to disasters. The Federal Emergency Management Agency responds to disasters by conducting emergency operations to save lives and property, providing food, water, shelter, and medical care, and restoring critical public services. They also focus on recovery by rebuilding communities and increasing efficiencies through coordination efforts. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 designates the Federal Emergency Management Agency as the lead agency for the Federal Response Plan. The Director of FEMA is required to revise the plan within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, technical and conforming amendments are made to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to make changes to sections 430(c) and 503, including redesignating paragraphs and updating the table of contents by striking the item relating to section 507. SEC. 103 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 emphasizes that the Department of Homeland Security's main goal is to protect the country from terrorist threats. In TITLE II, SEC. 201 defines key terms like "Federal agency" and "function," while SEC. 202 addresses the transfer of functions within the government. SEC. 202 of the Homeland Security Act transfers all functions previously held by the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency to the newly established agency. SEC. 203 outlines personnel provisions. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency may appoint officers and employees, including investigators and attorneys, in accordance with civil service laws. Experts and consultants can be hired at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Federal Emergency Management Agency can pay experts and consultants for travel expenses and per diem while away from their regular place of business, as authorized by specific sections. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency can delegate functions to designated officers and employees, with the ability for successive redelegations as needed. The Director remains responsible for the administration of these functions. Additionally, reorganization is authorized. SEC. 205. REORGANIZATION. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency can allocate functions among officers and adjust organizational entities as needed. SEC. 206. RULES. The Director can establish rules to manage agency functions. SEC. 207. TRANSFER AND ALLOCATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS AND PERSONNEL. SEC. 207. TRANSFER AND ALLOCATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS AND PERSONNEL. Personnel, assets, liabilities, contracts, property, records, and unexpended balances of funds related to transferred functions shall be moved to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Unexpended funds must be used for their original purposes. SEC. 208. INCIDENTAL TRANSFERS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to make determinations and dispositions of personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, property, and funds related to transferred functions. The termination of entities and necessary measures to carry out the provisions of this title will be provided. Transfer of personnel under this title shall not result in separation or reduction in grade or compensation for one year. Employees appointed to comparable positions in the Federal Emergency Management Agency will maintain their compensation levels. Employees transferred to new positions will maintain their previous compensation levels for the duration of their service in the new position. Employees transferred to new positions will maintain their previous compensation levels for the duration of their service in the new position. SEC. 210. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. The continuing effect of legal documents issued by the President, federal agencies, or courts in the performance of transferred functions will remain in effect until modified or revoked by the President or the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The provisions of this title do not affect any pending proceedings or applications before the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Orders issued in such proceedings will continue until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. The provisions of this title do not affect pending proceedings before the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Suits commenced before the effective date of this title will proceed as if the title had not been enacted. No actions against the agency or its officers will abate due to this title. Any administrative action related to the preparation or promulgation of regulations by the Federal Emergency Management Agency for functions transferred under this title can continue with the same effect as if this title had not been enacted. SEC. 211. SEPARABILITY. If a provision of this title is held invalid, the rest of the title is unaffected. SEC. 212. TRANSITION. The Director of FEMA can use personnel and funds for a smooth transition. SEC. 213. REFERENCES. SEC. 213. REFERENCES. Any reference in Federal law, Executive order, rule, or document pertaining to a department from which a function is transferred by this title is deemed to refer to the department to which the function is transferred. SEC. 214. ADDITIONAL CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency will prepare and submit recommended legislation for technical amendments after consulting with Congress and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. This must be done within 6 months of the effective date of the title.
